results.title: Amazing H2o
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Episode 2: amazing H2O’ starts with the story of Henry Cavendish (Mark Allen), a rich scientist in the 17th century who made it his mission in life to discover the properties of water. His persistence gave us the H2O chemical name. With 70% of the earth covered in water, it is surprising to learn that scientists know more about the qualities of ice than water itself. Exploring both the realm of the known and unknown, this episode covers the following topics; surface tension, anti-gravitational behaviour, solutions, emulsions, ice, gas, evaporation, crystals. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: The Water planet
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Waterworks”.
‘Waterworks’ is an in depth series produced by the ABC on water and covers areas such as; human usage, molecular properties and the role of water in the ecology. ‘The Water planet’, first in the series, details broadly the concepts that govern the function of water and investigates the presence of water on earth and in space. The film starts with the premise that all life on earth is based on water and digresses to detail this relationship. The following subjects are covered from the presence of water in space, water cycles, water ecology, function of chemical parts in water, weather patterns and its relationship to water, water and plantlife, the oceans. Presented by series producer Dick Beilby.

results.title: Elizabeth Jolley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
One of Australia’s most popular and acclaimed novelists, Elizabeth Jolley recalls her childhood and the influence of her Quaker upbringing in the industrial north of England. Jolley emigrated to Western Australia with her husband and three children and worked as a cleaner and travelling saleswoman to support her writing. Despite twenty years of rejection slips her first book of short fiction, “Five Acre Virgin and Other Stories” was eventually published in 1976. Another five books were released in the following six years and her radio plays were produced by both the ABC and the BBC World Service. Jolley asserts the importance of imagination over experience in her creative life and her belief in the value of regional fiction. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: writers III

results.title: Dorothy Hewett
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: writers III”.
Dorothy Hewett reflects on her life as a playwright, poet, author and teacher. Hewett grew up in Western Australia and has been a writer all her life. A political, social and sexual rebel, she has created work which has often been controversial for its frankness and for the power of her female central characters. In this 1991 interview, Hewett discusses the professional and personal relationships that have enriched her life and inspired her writing. She also speaks about ageing and her struggle to overcome the loss of physical power. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

results.title: La Mama
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on stage”.
Betty Burstall founded La Mama in Carlton, Melbourne, in 1967 as a venue for experimental theatre. During her nine years as Artistic Director, she encouraged playwrights, poets, actors and musicians to reject theatrical traditions and push the boundaries of performing art. La Mama is synonymous with the renaissance of Australian theatre. Playwrights such as Williamson, Buzo, Dickins, Romeril and Hibberd wrote about contemporary Australia. Actors rejected the formality of conventional theatre and developed a larrikin performance style which reflected a new awareness of cultural identity. In this engaging compilation film, Burstall, her successor Liz Jones, writers Barry Dickins and Jack Hibberd and performers Petter Cummins and Valerie Kirwin speak to Mary-Lou Jelbart about the challenges and joys of working at La Mama.

results.title: Peter Sculthorpe
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Peter Sculthorpe, Australia’s best-known contemporary composer, discusses his personal philosophy and the influences which have shaped his creative development. Sculthorpe studied at the Melbourne University Conservatorium of Music and at Oxford University. His “Sonatina for Piano” was performed at the International Society of Contemporary Music Festival in Baden-Baden in 1955 and he went on to receive international recognition with the success of his Sun Music series. Throughout his career, Sculthorpe has drawn on a diversity of cultural influences in his quest to develop uniquely Australian music. He has composed for film, television, theatre and opera as well as the concert platform, and enjoys the status of elder statesman among contemporary Australian composers. A performance of his work “Kakadu” in 1989 was a rallying point for Australian conservationists and since then Sculthorpe has used his music to promote environmental causes. Research and interview: James Murdoch.

group.title: Australia Council archival film series: on music

results.title: Alice Moyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australia Council archival film series: on music”.
Alice Moyle was born in South Africa on 25th December 1908 and spent her first four years there before migrating out to Australia with her parents. She learned the piano and studied music at school, attending the University of Melbourne Conservatorium where she graduated with a Bachelor of Music in 1930. Alice Moyle’s first experience of Aboriginal music was listening to recordings made by Professor Elkin when she was attending courses at the Faculty of Music at Sydney University. These recordings were to prepare teachers for work in the outback. In 1959 Alice made the first of many field trips into the outback to continue the process of recording and archiving Aboriginal music. She has continually tried to inspire others with her experiences and knowledge in Aboriginal music and culture and is adamant that music be included as an essential component in the study of Aboriginal culture. This documentary is a recorded interview between Alice Moyle and James Murdoch.
